com.ibm.xmi.framework
Class DefaultObjectWriterAdapter

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.ibm.xmi.framework.DefaultObjectWriterAdapter
All Implemented Interfaces:
ObjectWriterAdapter, WriterAdapter
public abstract class DefaultObjectWriterAdapter
extends java.lang.Object
implements ObjectWriterAdapter

This class is an abstract class that you can use to help you implement your own object writer adapter.

Some methods are implemented for you; these methods are ones that you need to implement to use more advanced XMI capabilities like XMI extensions, saving values of objects in a particular order, and providing UUIDs, labels, and hrefs for objects. By providing default implementations of these methods, you can ignore them if you are not using the advanced XMI capabilities they support. If you need to implement them, you can do so after you implement the required methods.

The methods that you need to implement are abstract; so you will get a compiler error if you inherit from this class to create your own object writer adapter until you provide an implementation for the required methods.

Fields inherited from interface com.ibm.xmi.framework.WriterAdapter

Method Detail

getContents

public java.util.Collection getContents(java.lang.Object data)
Return the contents of the given XMI extension, XML element, or package, or an empty collection if there are no contents.

Implement this method if you want XMI extensions to be written to an XMI file (and you are not using sets of tag values to do it), or if you want a package to be written to a DTD or schema.

Specified by:
getContents in interface WriterAdapter
Parameters:
data - An XMI extension, XML element, or package
Returns:
The contents of the given construct

getFeatures

public java.util.Collection getFeatures(java.lang.Object xmiClass)
Return a collection of features for the given class, or an empty collection if there are no features. This method is used when serializing values of objects if the values need to be serialized according to the order of features of classes. This method is also used when creating XMI DTDs and schemas.
Specified by:
getFeatures in interface WriterAdapter
Parameters:
xmiClass - An object corresponding to an XMIClass
Returns:
The features for the class, or an empty collection

getNamespace

public abstract Namespace getNamespace(java.lang.Object data)
Return the namespace name for the given data.
Specified by:
getNamespace in interface WriterAdapter
Parameters:
data - A Java object representing data to write to a file or dtd.
Returns:
The namespace name, or null if there is none.

getOwner

public abstract java.lang.Object getOwner(java.lang.Object data)
Return the owner for the given piece of data. If data corresponds to a framework value, the owner is the object it belongs to. If data corresponds to a framework feature, the owner is the class it belongs to. If data corresponds to a class, the owner is the package it belongs to. If data is a package, the owner is the package that contains it.

The framework uses this method when computing XMI names.

Specified by:
getOwner in interface WriterAdapter
Parameters:
data - An object representing either a package, class, feature, or value.
Returns:
The owner, or null if there is none.

object - An XMI object
Returns:
A vector of strings, or an empty vector.

getDefiner

public java.lang.Object getDefiner(java.lang.Object data)
Return a Java object that represents the definer of the given object or value. An object's definer is its class; a value of an object is defined by the corresponding feature in the object's class.

You need to implement this method if the order that values of objects are serialized is important. This is so for XMI 1.0 and for XMI 2.0 if schemas are generated that define an order.

Specified by:
getDefiner in interface ObjectWriterAdapter
Parameters:
data - Your Java object that corresponds to a class or a feature
Returns:
The definer, or null, if there is none.

getHref

public java.lang.String getHref(java.lang.Object object)
Return an href for the given object. This method may return null. This method only needs to return a string if you wish to set the href for cross-file links yourself; otherwise, the framework will create an href for you.
Specified by:
getHref in interface ObjectWriterAdapter
Parameters:
object - Your Java object that corresponds to a framework XMIObject
Returns:
The href, or null, if there is none.

getId

public java.lang.String getId(java.lang.Object object)
Return an XMI Id for the given object; if this method returns null, the XMI Framework will create an Id for each of your objects when writing them to an XMI file. If your application uses Ids, and you want to preserve them, you can return your own Id, which must be unique for the objects in an XMI file.
Specified by:
getId in interface ObjectWriterAdapter
Parameters:
object - Your Java object that corresponds to a framework XMIObject
Returns:
The Id, or null, if there is none.

setId

public void setId(java.lang.Object object,
                  java.lang.String id)
Set the id for the given object to the given value. The framework only calls this method for cross-file references, where the object that is referenced in another file does not have an id assigned to it.

When the framework invokes getId with the given object, you need to return the id assigned by the framework, to ensure that cross-file references are serialized correctly.

Specified by:
setId in interface ObjectWriterAdapter
Parameters:
object - An object corresponding to a framework XMI object.
id - The id created by the framework.

Specified by:
getLabel in interface ObjectWriterAdapter
Parameters:
object - Your Java object that corresponds to a framework XMIObject
Returns:
The label, or null, if there is none.

Specified by:
getValues in interface ObjectWriterAdapter
Parameters:

Returns:
A collection of java.lang.Objects corresponding to the values, or an empty collection, if there are no values

getXMIFile

public java.lang.String getXMIFile(java.lang.Object object)
Return an XMI file name for the given object. You do not need to implement this method unless you want to split your data into several XMI files, in which case you need to specify which file your objects will be stored in so the framework can properly create cross-file references.

You do not need to implement this method if you return your own hrefs in the getHref method.

Specified by:
getXMIFile in interface ObjectWriterAdapter
Parameters:
object - Your Java object that corresponds to a framework XMIObject
Returns:
The name of the XMI file, or null, if there is none.

getXMLAttributes

public java.util.Collection getXMLAttributes(java.lang.Object xmlElement)
Return a collection consisting of the names of the XML attributes for the given xmlElement, followed by their values, or an empty collection if there are no attributes for the XML element.
Specified by:
getXMLAttributes in interface ObjectWriterAdapter
Parameters:
xmlElement - An XML element
Returns:
A collection of attribute names followed by values

getFeatureType

public java.lang.Object getFeatureType(java.lang.Object feature)
Return the type of a feature. This will be an object representing either a framework datatype, enumeration, or class.
Specified by:
getFeatureType in interface WriterAdapter
Parameters:
feature - An object corresponding to a framework feature.
Returns:
The type of the feature, or null.

setXMIFile

public void setXMIFile(XMIFile xmiFile)
This method is invoked before the header is written. It allows you to access the XMI file to set header data or other file options before the framework writes the header.
Specified by:
setXMIFile in interface ObjectWriterAdapter
Parameters:
xmiFile - The XMI file to be written
